data.title: Several versions of vscode after update
data.body:
After updating now the second time vscode, I can now right-click a file and open it with 3 different versions of it: 1.6.1, 1.8.1 & 1.9.0.

How can I either automatically prevent this on an update or remove the old versions after the updates? Many thanks in advance!

My OS Version is: Mac OSX 10.11.5

- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0

|---|---|---|

        LANG = "en.UTF-8"
    are supported and installed on your system.
perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
```

It works fine in the default terminal, or in Hyper.

1. Have editor set to 2 spaces for tabs
2. Save a *.js file that is following the 2 spaces rule
3. The tabbing is changed to 4 spaces

Also note, this is my settings file at the moment:

```
{
    // layout
    "workbench.sideBar.location": "right",
    // font
    "editor.fontFamily": "ubuntu mono, Menlo, Monaco, 'Courier New', monospace",
    "editor.fontSize": 14,

    // viewport

    // formating
    "editor.detectIndentation": false,
    "editor.tabSize": 2,
    "editor.formatOnType": false, // not sure on this one


    // autocomplete
    "editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": false,

    // cursor
    "editor.cursorBlinking": "blink",


    // Eslint
    "eslint.run": "onType",
    "workbench.activityBar.visible": true,
    "workbench.statusBar.visible": true,
    "window.zoomLevel": 0,
    "files.associations": {
        "*.js": "javascript"
    },
    "editor.tabCompletion": false,
    "vsicons.projectDetection.autoReload": true,
    "[javascript]": {

}

data.title: Explore using a native third-party search tool such as ripgrep or Silver Searcher

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am very impressed with the performance of the new parallel search; however, there is an opportunity to take search speed to the absolute limit by optionally allowing a user to configure ripgrep as the search provider.

Even with the new search speed, ripgrep is still an order of magnitude faster.  Ripgrep is actually an order of magnitude faster than pretty much anything.

http://blog.burntsushi.net/ripgrep/

data.title: Text selection is very slow
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
Version 1.9.0
Commit 27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af
Date 2017-02-02T08:21:13.228Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0

- OS Version:
Arch Linux, 4.4.42-1-lts

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a big file (in my case ~8.5k lines) 
2. Try to select 20 lines with mouse drag
3. See it taking 3-4 seconds with freezes.


I wonder it has something to do with the "selected word count" function being called each time a word is selected, which is shown in statusbar.

data.title: Coloration issue
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file
2. Add a bunch of lines of code (or don't)

You may be able to notice that the coloration isn't quite correct across the editor. There are rectangles of a darker shade of gray around any lines of code you wrote, so if there is a long line of code, there is a long rectangle of darker gray. There is also a rectangle around the lines that you currently are typing in. However, the rest of the background behind the code is an ever so slightly lighter shade of gray. The darker shade is 1e1e1e and the lighter shade is 212121. The difference is extremely apparent to me whenever I am using the software.

![vscode-coloration](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5074313/22626369/a7cc1132-eb79-11e6-9a29-0844dcc82955.jpg)


The top half is of 1e1e1e and the bottom half is of 212121 in this particular screenshot

data.title: unable to debug nodejs code written in es6 + async await and transpiled  with babel.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.9.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. clone this repository :https://github.com/talarari/vscode-debug/tree/master
2. run ```npm run build``` to transpile code with babel
3. run ``` npm install```      
4. set breakpoints in src/async-await.js like this (the breakpoints will move when you actually try to run...):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4973087/22625964/0392a482-ebab-11e6-82bb-90198e670c00.png)
5. launch the project from inside vscode like this:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4973087/22625968/1832c0a2-ebab-11e6-85f3-d899839a3a5f.png)

breakpoints will break in unexpected places, stepping into and over will go to unexpected places, basically debugging will not be possible.

vscode code has an awesome debugging experience, but faced with the option of debugging vs writing async-await code, the latter wins.

would really like to have both :)    
i've tried many different setups and none worked.
any project setup that will work is fine by me (babel-node,building source before running, advanced versions of node , anything else you can think of).    

if there is one that works, just fork my repo and make the needed changes.
any help will be greatly appreciated.

data.title: TypeScript: Global variables and functions marked duplicate
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Ran into this while learning TypeScript.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an empty folder with a new TypeScript file helloWorld.ts in VS Code.
2. Type in declaration `let my_var : number = 100`
3. Compile into a .js file into the same folder using command `tsc helloWorld.ts` (compile succeeds without warnings)
4. Open compiled .js in VS Code (either in right pane or in a new tab).
5. Navigate back to the open TypeScript file.
6. Add a space to the file.

At this point, `my_var` is underlined in red and the tooltip on hovering over it says:

[ts] Cannot redeclare block-scoped variable 'my_var'.
let my_var: number

One can observe a similar behavior with functions, where VS Code claims there is one more override somewhere, ie

[ts] Duplicate function implementation.
function doNothing(): void (+1 overload)

![2017-02-05 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15193589/22625862/09e1bd4e-ebc6-11e6-94e4-ac000437422a.png)

VS Code marks the function / variable as duplicate only when it is present in the compiled .js file.

Deleting the .js file makes the underlines go away.

data.title: Fuzzy Search in Cmd palette should rank results with closer search terms higher (fixes #14727)
Error when trying to use the `lzma-native` npm module
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Fedora 25

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new extension using `yo code`
2. Add the `lzma-native` npm module as dependency
3. Import the module and use it in the extension (simply `console.log`ging it is enough)
4. Start the extension debug mode

VSCode gives the error message `Here is the error stack:  Error: Module version mismatch. Expected 50, got 48.`. The problem could be coming from the `lzma-native` module, but so far using the module outside of VSCode seems to work just fine.

This module uses `node-pre-gyp` to provide ready-to-use precompiled binaries. Could the error be related to this ?

data.title: git clone nvm with --depth 1, to make clone faster
data.body:
nvm git repo has 1500+ commits, there's no need to clone the full repo.
So add `--depth 1` when git clone to make it faster

data.title: Tasks not running in project stored on network file share
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro Build 1607

I have a TypeScript project stored on a Samba file share that I access remotely from a number of computers and I am unable to run tasks in that project when using Windows 10. There's no output or error message, the task just fails to run.

This is my tasks.json:

```json
{
	"version": "0.1.0",
	"command": "echo",
	"isShellCommand": true,
	"args": ["Hello World"],
	"showOutput": "always"
}
```
When I run the task on Windows 10 there is no output produced.
When I run the task on MacOS Sierra 10.12.3 the output 'Hello World' is produced as expected.

If I then copy the project folder from the file share to the local disk on Windows I am able to run the task and it outputs 'Hello World' as expected. 

I have also tested this with the TypeScript compiler in watch mode using the following tasks.json:

```json
{
	"version": "0.1.0",
	"command": "tsc",
	"isShellCommand": true,
	"args": ["-w", "-p", "."],
	"showOutput": "silent",
	"isWatching": true,
	"problemMatcher": "$tsc-watch"
}
```

This yields similar results. It runs fine on MacOS and also runs fine when I copy the project folder to my local disk, but will not run on Windows 10 from the file share.

Surprisingly though I can execute the following from either cmd or powershell and the watcher works as it should: 

```
tsc -w -p [path to project]
```

Any idea why this might be happening?

data.title: A Pane to List Todos Neatly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: Linux Mint

This is an enhancement request.

I drop todos all over my projects, and there needs to be a proper way to find all of them in a list with links to the position in the file. There are two problems with code that is hindering the development of a fully featured plugin to perform this task.

1. Each language must have a documentation for what the comment syntax is so that it does not have to be done manually for the extension developers.

2. There needs to be a pane to display all of todos clearly, or html must be allowed on the output pane so that the output actually looks beautiful. I really like the look and feel of the error pane(shown below), and it would be great if there was a pane where we could list the todos in a similar manner.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6607952/22624334/51ee250e-eb36-11e6-9568-2d4f76e2e8f5.png)

data.title: Yaml and Markdown yaml front matter doesn't like single digit months or days
data.body:
According to the YAML spec http://yaml.org/type/timestamp.html, single digits are allowed:

>  -[0-9][0-9]? # (month)
>  -[0-9][0-9]? # (day)

Note this applies to both the front matter section at the top of a markdown file (as below) and in a `.yml` file

Test text:

```
---
date1 : 2016-8-2
date1 : 2016-8-20
date1 : 2016-08-2
date1 : 2016-08-20
date2 : 2016-11-20
---
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/22624179/398edf2a-eb28-11e6-8fd1-2feb228cdef2.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/22624184/47c199b6-eb28-11e6-927d-7f0ee2f6b0af.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/22624183/4114c17e-eb28-11e6-85d1-03e0df70ce02.png)
